abstract: The Justice Department is demanding that some of Wall Street’s biggest banks plead guilty to criminal charges in order to settle a long-running investigation.
snippet: The Justice Department is demanding that some of Wall Street’s biggest banks plead guilty to criminal charges in order to settle a long-running investigation.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is pushing some of the biggest banks on Wall Street — including, for the first time in decades, American institutions — to plead guilty to criminal charges that they manipulated the prices of foreign currencies.

headline.main: Justice Department Is Seeking Felony Pleas by Big Banks in Foreign Currency Inquiry
headline.print_headline: U.S. Is Seeking Felony Pleas by Big Banks

byline.original: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

abstract: The Justice Department is pushing banks to plead guilty to settle a currency inquiry. | A disproportionate number of companies led by women are the targets of activist investors. | Puerto Rico’s debt plan is in jeopardy. | Profit at UBS rises.
snippet: The Justice Department is pushing banks to plead guilty to settle a currency inquiry. | A disproportionate number of companies led by women are the targets of activist investors. | Puerto Rico’s debt plan is in jeopardy. | Profit at UBS rises.
lead_paragraph: U.S. SEEKS FELONY PLEAS BY BIG BANKS | The Justice Department is pushing some of the biggest banks on Wall Street, including American institutions, to plead guilty to criminal charges that they manipulated the prices of foreign currencies, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook. In the final stages of a long-running investigation into corruption in the world’s biggest financial market, federal prosecutors have recently informed Barclays, JPMorgan Chase, the Royal Bank of Scotland and Citigroup that they must enter guilty pleas to settle the cases, according to lawyers briefed on the matter.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: U.S. Presses Banks for Guilty Pleas
